body_html:
Since data in that example is a tf.data.Dataset object, an API like that would require some form of mutability in the Dataset class, which we are not going to support.

It might be possible to define some new type that supports (i) maintaining a dynamic set of elements, and (ii) creating a Dataset over that dynamic set of elements that has well-defined semantics (e.g. it could randomly sample from the current set of elements, or cycle through the elements in FIFO order).
body_text:
Since data in that example is a tf.data.Dataset object, an API like that would require some form of mutability in the Dataset class, which we are not going to support.
It might be possible to define some new type that supports (i) maintaining a dynamic set of elements, and (ii) creating a Dataset over that dynamic set of elements that has well-defined semantics (e.g. it could randomly sample from the current set of elements, or cycle through the elements in FIFO order).
body:
Since `data` in that example is a `tf.data.Dataset` object, an API like that would require some form of mutability in the `Dataset` class, which we are not going to support.

It might be possible to define some new type that supports (i) maintaining a dynamic set of elements, and (ii) creating a `Dataset` over that dynamic set of elements that has well-defined semantics (e.g. it could randomly sample from the current set of elements, or cycle through the elements in FIFO order).
